question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: What was Albie Wax's NCAA Division I basketball league as of 2040?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

Albie Wax

Albie Wax is a former American college basketball player who played in the NCAA Division I men's basketball league during the 1961-1962 season. Early Life and College Career

Albie Wax was born in the United States and attended Columbia University, where he played college basketball for the Columbia Lions men's basketball team. NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Career

Wax played in the NCAA Division I men's basketball league during the 1961-1962 season, representing Columbia University. During his time in the league, Wax was a member of the Columbia Lions men's basketball team that competed against other top-tier college basketball programs in the United States. Evidence of Wax's participation in the NCAA Division I men's basketball league can be found in various credible sources, including:

* The 1962 Columbia University athletic department's media guide, which lists Wax as a member of the men's basketball team. [1]
* A newspaper article from the New York Times, dated February 10, 1962, which mentions Wax's performance in a game against Harvard University. [2]
* The NCAA's official website, which recognizes Columbia University as a Division I member institution and lists Wax as a player on the 1961-1962 roster. [3]

References:

[1] Columbia University Athletic Department. (1962). 1962 Columbia University Athletic Department Media Guide. Retrieved from <https:\/\/library.columbia.edu\/ldpdigital\/cul:kr6x94s8vq>

[2] New York Times. (1962, February 10). Harvard Defeats Columbia, 73-67. Retrieved from <https:\/\/www.nytimes.com\/1962\/02\/10\/archives\/harvard-defeats-columbia-7367.html>

[3] National Collegiate Athletic Association. (n.d.). NCAA Division I Member Institutions. Retrieved from <https:\/\/www.ncaa.org\/about\/resources\/research\/division-i-member-institutions>

The 102-year-old Wax will become the oldest player to ever participate in the NCAA Division I women's basketball league. When asked about his decision to join the league, Wax said, "I never thought I'd get the chance to play again, especially at my age. But with the advancements in medicine and technology, I feel like I'm in better shape now than I was back in my college days." Wax's decision to join the league has also sparked a heated debate about the age limit for college athletes. "This is a game-changer," said NCAA President, Mark Emmert. "We're going to have to re-evaluate our policies and consider the implications of allowing older athletes to compete." As Wax prepares to take the court, fans and critics alike are eagerly awaiting his debut. Will he be able to keep up with the younger competition, or will his age prove to be a hindrance?
